bioghist.p: From 1982 to 1999 Brenda Dixon Gottschild was Professor of Dance Studies at Temple University. She received her Ph.D. from New York University. As a dance scholar and a cultural historian, she has worked to highlight the Africanist presence in European-based American concert dance. In addition to her scholarly work, Dixon Gottschild is a practicing choreographer and performer; in collaboration with her husband Hellmut Gottschild, she created and performed Stick it Out (1993), Frogs (1996), and Tongue Smell Color (2000). They continue to perform Tongue Smell Color internationally. Dixon Gottschild is the Philadelphia correspondent for Dance Magazine. Her book, The Black Dancing Body: A Geography from Coon to Cool, was published in 2003. Previous books include Waltzing in the Dark: African American Vaudeville and Race Politics in the Swing Era, and Digging the Africanist Presence in American Performance: Dance and Other Contexts.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of Brenda Dixon Gottschild. Materials include notes, manuscripts, and reference materials for her books, magazine articles, reviews, and lectures; published articles and reviews; press releases and flyers for lectures and publications; conference and grant files; a small amount of correspondence related to academic positions and publications; printed and audio materials used for courses; and programs and posters for dance performances. The collection includes numerous audio cassette recordings and transcripts of interviews with various subjects, including Meredith Monk, Margot Webb, Marion Cuyjet, Ralph Lemon, Arthur Hall, Merian Soto, and many others. Some of these recordings were made as part of the Black Philly Dance Project in the 1980s.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
